claim: Value innovation occurs when you simultaneously pursue differentiation and low cost, breaking the traditional trade-off. Eliminate and reduce factors to lower cost; raise and create factors to lift value.
rationale: Red ocean logic forces choice between differentiation (higher cost) and low cost (less value). Value innovation rejects this by reconstructing buyer value elements to achieve both simultaneously.

claim: Use the Four Actions Framework: Eliminate factors the industry takes for granted. Reduce factors below standard. Raise factors above standard. Create factors the industry never offered.
rationale: This framework forces systematic reconstruction of buyer value elements. Eliminating and reducing drives cost down; raising and creating drives differentiation up—achieving both simultaneously.

claim: A good strategy has three qualities on the strategy canvas: focus (emphasises few factors), divergence (stands apart from competitors), and a compelling tagline (communicates essence to buyers).
rationale: Converging value curves signal red ocean competition. Focus prevents overdelivery. Divergence ensures differentiation. A tagline tests whether the strategy can be simply communicated.

claim: Most blue oceans are created from within red oceans by expanding industry boundaries, not by inventing entirely new industries. Look across alternatives, strategic groups, buyer chains, and time.
rationale: Creating within the core business allows companies to leverage existing knowledge and capabilities. The six paths framework provides systematic ways to reconstruct market boundaries.

claim: Reach beyond existing demand by focusing on noncustomers. Three tiers: soon-to-be (minimally using, ready to leave), refusing (consciously opted out), and unexplored (never considered the industry).
rationale: Traditional strategy focuses on existing customers, leading to finer segmentation and smaller markets. Noncustomers reveal why people avoid the industry, uncovering pain points that limit boundaries.

claim: Build strategy in sequence: buyer utility first (exceptional value), then strategic price (accessible to mass), then target cost (profitable at that price), then adoption (win over stakeholders).
rationale: Wrong sequence wastes effort. If utility fails, rethink idea. If price fails, mass can't buy. If cost fails, innovate business model. If adoption fails, execution is blocked.

claim: Technology innovation without buyer value innovation fails. Don't be obsessed with technology; focus on how it improves buyers' lives through simplicity, convenience, or productivity.
rationale: Philips CD-i and Motorola Iridium were technological marvels that failed because they didn't offer compelling utility for target users. Value innovation links innovation to what buyers actually value.

claim: Focusing only on existing customers leads to incremental improvements within red oceans. Customers ask for 'more for less' of existing features, not envisioning new market spaces.
rationale: Customers benchmark against what exists. Noncustomers reveal why people avoid the industry entirely, uncovering opportunities to redefine boundaries that customer research misses.

claim: Cirque du Soleil eliminated costly circus elements (animals, star performers, multiple arenas) while adding theatre elements (storyline, artistic music), achieving differentiation at lower cost.
rationale: Instead of competing with traditional circuses, Cirque created new entertainment appealing to adults and corporate clients. Made competition irrelevant by reconstructing buyer value elements.

claim: [yellow tail] by Casella Wines eliminated complexity and aging quality emphasis, reduced price versus premium, raised fun and adventure—creating easy-drinking wine that attracted noncustomers.
rationale: Applied Four Actions Framework to create wine for people who didn't drink wine. Focused on easy selection, fun packaging, and approachable taste rather than traditional wine factors.

claim: Southwest Airlines focused on friendly service, speed, and frequent point-to-point departures. Diverged from traditional airlines with tagline: 'The speed of a plane at the price of a car.'
rationale: Eliminated meals, lounges, hub routing, seating choices. Created value curve with focus (few factors), divergence (different from competitors), and compelling tagline.

claim: Six paths to reconstruct market boundaries: look across alternative industries, strategic groups, buyer chains, complementary offerings, functional-emotional appeal, and time (trends).
rationale: Each path challenges conventional assumptions that keep companies trapped. Systematic exploration reveals opportunities to combine decisive advantages while eliminating irrelevant factors.

claim: Misalignment of value, profit, and people propositions causes promising blue oceans to fail. All three must reinforce each other around both differentiation and low cost.
rationale: Tata Nano had compelling value and profit propositions but weak people proposition for external stakeholders (community land issues), causing delays that dampened success.

claim: Blue ocean strategies face barriers to imitation: alignment complexity, cognitive/organisational inertia of competitors, brand reputation, economies of scale, network effects, and legal protections.
rationale: The integrated system of value, profit, and people propositions is hard to replicate piecemeal. Competitors' conventional thinking and internal politics delay response.

claim: Confusing blue ocean strategy with differentiation strategy is a red ocean trap. Differentiation offers premium value at higher cost/price. Blue ocean achieves differentiation AND low cost simultaneously.
rationale: Red ocean differentiation forces the value-cost trade-off. Blue ocean breaks it by eliminating/reducing factors while raising/creating others. It's 'and-and' not 'either-or'.
